entry.title: Why Choose SAP Business One Over Traditional ERP for SMEs?
entry.content:
Why Choose SAP Business One Over Traditional ERP for SMEs?

Article Teaser:
Small and mid-sized businesses often struggle with large ERP systems built for big corporations. SAP Business One offers a leaner, smarter alternative designed specifically for SMEs. But what makes it stand out? Let‚Äôs explore the differences and why it often wins.

A Simple View: Traditional ERP vs SAP Business One

Traditional ERPs are powerful but they come with high cost, long setup time, and heavy processes. For many SMEs, this means delays and overhead.

SAP Business One is built for smaller operations. It connects finance, sales, inventory and operations in one system. It supports on-premise or cloud deployment. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

Key Advantages for SMEs

  • Speed and Cost-Efficiency: SAP Business One uses fewer resources to deploy and maintain. SMEs can start faster and without heavy budgets. 
  • Built-In Modules for Core Functions: Finance, CRM, inventory, production and reporting all in one system. This reduces silos and errors.
  • Real-Time Insights and Reporting: Leaders make decisions quickly based on live data, not just past reports. 
  • Scalability and Flexibility: Though built for SMEs, the system grows with you adding users or modules as needed. 

When Traditional ERP Still Makes Sense

If your business is very large, highly global, or has ultra-complex processes, a full enterprise ERP might still be the right choice. But for most SMEs needing speed, clarity and cost control, SAP Business One hits the balance.

Practical Example

Imagine an SME with multiple warehouses, global sales, and service calls. With SAP Business One you get:

  • Visible inventory across locations.
  • Sales orders are linked directly to stock and deliveries.
  • Finance sees profit by product, region, or season in a few clicks.
  • Compliance and audits are easier because data is in one system.

Instead of juggling spreadsheets and multiple tools, everything lives in one system made for your size.

Conclusion

For SMEs seeking a business system that delivers strength without the overhead of full enterprise ERP, SAP Business One offers a compelling option. It connects core functions, gives live data to decision-makers, scales with growth, and keeps costs in check.

entry.title: Is a special SAP license required for Power Automate RPA, or is a standard Named User sufficient?
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

Context : We use Power Automate Desktop (PAD) to automate SAP ECC via SAP GUI Scripting for report export and MB21 posting (GUI only; no API/connector).

Our understanding:

  • Because access is via SAP GUI (direct), the bot should be licensed as a standard SAP Named User (BOT account), not as an SAP ‚ÄúRPA user‚Äù and not under Digital/Indirect Access (that would apply if we used non-SAP front-ends/API creating the 9 Digital Access document types).

  • Microsoft licensing is separate: cloud scheduling/unattended would require Power Automate Premium. (Today we‚Äôre attended/manual.)

Questions to confirm (please answer Yes/No):

  1. For PAD via SAP GUI, is a special SAP RPA license required? Or is a standard Named User for the BOT account sufficient under our contract?

  2. Which Named User class should we assign to the BOT (Professional vs Limited), given it creates MB21 reservations?

  3. Can we proceed to create a dedicated BOT account (Dialog or Service) with least-privilege roles and restrict GUI Scripting (S_SCR) to this BOT only?

  4. If in the future we switch to API/connector flows, should we then evaluate Digital Access (document-based) separately?

If this looks right, we‚Äôll proceed with a BOT Named User and keep runs attended until any Premium licensing is approved.

Thanks!

Richard

entry.title: Install custom functions in COHV (3/3)
entry.content:
Introduction

The previous two episodes have demonstrated how to create and register a custom mass processing function code in COHV as well as have provided an outline of the actual implementation of the mass processing. However, the implementation has not done anything useful, yet.

Now, it is the time to add some meat to the implementation and dive into more advanced topics like test mode, function parametrization and order updates.

 

Test mode

Let us start with test mode. Typically, SAP standard mass processing functions provide a test mode option that runs all data processing without actually saving any changes or updates. That is particularly useful if you want to test a mass processing run without committing the updates.
Figure 1 Test mode on

Figure 2 Test mode off

The implementation of the mass processing function does not need to explicitly handle test mode operation, i.e. either to rollback or commit changes. That is done by COHV backbone. Make sure to test thoroughly if the test mode is used to make sure that the custom mass processing function is compatible with the test mode handling in COHV. If you are not sure, the rule of thumb is not to use the test mode.

 

Passing parameters to the mass processing function

Mass processing functions can be supplied with additional parameters. That is often used in SAP standard functions, and it can be enabled for custom ones.

First, additional parameters need to be added to the transparent table and the dialog structure that have been created in the episode 2. Make sure to add the same fields of the same type to the table and to the structure.
Figure 3 The transparent table with a parameter

Figure 4 The dialog structure with a parameter

Once that is done, the parameter will appear in COHV.
Figure 6 The function's parameter in COHV

 

Mass processing logic implementation

Now, let‚Äôs implement the mass processing logic to update production orders. My goal is to change production orders quantity by the value passed with the function parameter. The implementation goes into Z_CO_WORK999_EXEX_SINGLE function. Refer to the previous episode for the details of the function creation.
Figure 7 A snippet of the mass processing logic implementation

Here is the entire implementation of the custom mass processing logic, which consists of the following steps:

  1. Get a production order number from LS_COWBPAR-OBJNR
  2. Read the order‚Äôs header details with the BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL function
  3. Modify the order quantity by the value of the function parameter. It is available in the LS_COWBPAR-QTYCHANGE field
  4. Update the order with the BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE function
*** BEGIN custom mass processing logic
   DATA:
     prodord    TYPE cowrk_s_prodord_mask,
     return     TYPE bapiret2,
     headers    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_order_header1,
     orderdata  TYPE bapi_pp_order_change,
     orderdatax TYPE bapi_pp_order_changex,
     dummy      TYPE string.
 
  prodord = ls_cowbpar-objnr.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL'
     EXPORTING
       number        = prodord-aufnr
       order_objects = VALUE bapi_pp_order_objects( header = abap_true )
     TABLES
       header        = headers.
 
  READ TABLE headers INDEX 1 ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<header>).
   orderdata-quantity = <header>-target_quantity + ls_cowbpar-qtychange.
   orderdatax-quantity = abap_true.
 
  CLEAR return.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE'
     EXPORTING
       number     = prodord-aufnr
       orderdata  = orderdata
       orderdatax = orderdatax
     IMPORTING
       return     = return.
 
  IF return IS INITIAL.
     MESSAGE s100(co) WITH prodord-aufnr INTO dummy.
   ELSE.
     MESSAGE ID return-id TYPE return-type NUMBER return-number
     WITH return-message_v1 return-message_v2 return-message_v3 return-message_v4
     INTO dummy.
   ENDIF.
 
  ls_context-aufnr = ls_exec_obj-aufnr.
   CALL FUNCTION 'CO_APPLLOG_WRITE_SYMSG'
     EXPORTING
       i_loghandle           = ls_appllog-log_handle
       i_syst                = syst
       is_context            = ls_context
     EXCEPTIONS
       application_log_error = 1
       OTHERS                = 2.
 *** END custom mass processing logic

entry.title: üöÄ What‚Äôs New in Floorplan Manager (FPM) for Web Dynpro ABAP in SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

When it comes to the design of web-based user interfaces, SAP truly has a rich history. A great example is the EPM Purchase Order Demo (FPM/WDA application S_EPM_FPM_PO) (see Figure 1):

Figure 1: Application S_EPM_FPM_PO ‚Äì Design evolution over the years

Design themes such as Tradeshow, Corbusier, Belize, or Quartz are well known to many developers. But the journey doesn‚Äôt end there ‚Äî it continues toward new Horizons and compliance with the WCAG 2.2 Accessibility Standard.

In the latest releases, several new features have been added to the Floorplan Manager (FPM) / Web Dynpro ABAP framework, driven by customer feedback, SAP design standards, and general product evolution. With the ABAP Platform 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025 (on-premise, private cloud, and public cloud editions), we are delivering several enhancements that can be activated easily ‚Äî either automatically through delivery or manually with minimal configuration or coding effort.

üß≠ Page Header UIBBs & Object Page Mode

In one of my previous blogs on S/4HANA 2023, üëâ Team FPM: How to Render an FPM Overview Page to Look Like a SAP Fiori Object Page, I introduced the Object Page Mode for the Overview Page (OVP) floorplan.

This mode allows you to render an FPM Overview Page application like a Fiori Object Page. Combined with a Page Header UIBB, you get a dynamic object header that automatically expands and collapses while scrolling. You can also pin the header to keep it fixed. You can easily try this out in the Search Page of the EPM Purchase Order Demo (see Figure 2).

Figure 2: S_EPM_FPM_PO with Page Header, Pin and List Item Navigation

The new List-Item Navigation lets users navigate to a Purchase Order‚Äôs detail page in a Fiori-compliant way. On the detail page, the Object Page Mode provides faster and more precise scrolling to specific screen areas (sections or UIBBs) using the Anchor Bar or Navigation Bar (see Figure 3).

Figure 3: Purchase Order Detail Page with Anchor Bar

Configuration

  • Object Page Mode is activated in the General Settings as a Floorplan Mode (see Figure 4).
  • To use a dynamic object header, define a Page Header Area in the layout and add Page Header UIBBs.

Figure 4: Object Page Mode setting in FLUID for OVP Floorplan S_EPM_UX_PO_OVP

In the List or Tree UIBB, a List-Item Navigation corresponds to rendering a Link-To-Action column differently. You can achieve this by checking Render as Navigation Column in the column configuration (see Figure 5).

Figure 5: Setting ‚ÄúPurchase Order ID‚Äù as Navigation Column in FLUID for List UIBB EPM_PO_OVP_SEARCH_LIST_CFG

Additional Remarks

Some OVP floorplan features may behave differently in Object Page Mode. This can affect:

  • Header rendering
  • UIBB Selector and Page Master splitter control
  • Section and UIBB stacking
  • Personalization and panel behavior

However, Power User Modes allow overriding some restrictions ‚Äî such as enabling drag-and-drop for UIBBs, expanding and collapsing panels, or rearranging layout elements.

üß© CSS Grid Layout & WCAG 2.2 Compliance

Another major improvement is the WCAG 2.2-compliant rendering of forms. We‚Äôve significantly enhanced the responsiveness of the Form/Repeater UIBB (GL2) by adopting a CSS Grid Layout.

This ensures that forms remain usable and readable ‚Äî even at screen widths as low as 320px (mobile phone format) ‚Äî without horizontal scrolling (see Figure 6).

 Figure 6: ‚ÄúPurchase Order Details‚Äù form in different screen sizes

In the configuration editor (FLUID), you can enable the CSS Grid layout at General Settings ‚Üí Layout Design Type ‚Üí Responsive (see Figure 7).

Figure 7: FLUID configuration for Form UIBB EPM_PO_OVP_HEADER_FORM_CFG

üí¨Message Toasts & Invisible Alerts

In this context, it‚Äôs worth mentioning the Message Toast and Invisible Alert features, which enhance both usability and accessibility. A Message Toast is a small, non-disruptive popup for success messages that disappears automatically after a few seconds (see Figure 8). The  IF_FPM_MESSAGE_MANAGER ABAP interface now provides the REPORT_MESSAGE_TOAST method for this purpose. You can also enable a Toast Mode globally with the SET_TOAST_MODE( IV_TOAST_MODE = GC_TOAST_MODE-ENABLED ) method,  ensuring that messages of severity Success (S) are displayed as toasts by default (see also SAP Help Portal).

Figure 8: ‚ÄúData Saved‚Äù Toast in S_EPM_FPM_PO

An Invisible Alert, on the other hand, is used to inform screen reader users about content changes that are visible but not triggered by them ‚Äî ensuring WCAG 2.2 compliance. Use the REPORT_INVISIBLE_ALERT method from the IF_FPM_MESSAGE_MANAGER interface for this purpose.

üîôFLP Back Navigation

Finally, let us introduce Back Navigation in the SAP Fiori Launchpad (FLP).

You can now configure where the FLP back button should navigate to. By default, it goes back to the previous application, but often it‚Äôs more useful to return to the previous page within the same application. For example, when navigating from a main page to an edit page, you likely want the back button to return to the main page of the same object. Further details are available in SAP Help Portal.

‚úÖSummary

With SAP S/4HANA 2025, the Floorplan Manager for Web Dynpro ABAP continues its evolution toward:

  • A Fiori-consistent Object Page experience
  • Improved accessibility (WCAG 2.2)
  • More responsive layouts
  • Enhanced user feedback mechanisms (message toasts, invisible alerts)
  • Smarter navigation handling in the Fiori Launchpad

These innovations make it easier than ever for FPM-based applications to deliver a modern, accessible, and consistent user experience ‚Äî across all S/4HANA deployment options.

Thank you for reading ‚Äî and see you next time! üòä

entry.title: Re: Payroll EG Issue ‚Äì Need to Process Salaries in Non-EG...
entry.content:
Hello,

If your employees are assigned to company codes that are located outside Egypt, then you need to install the appropriate localization for these companies countries. The basis consultant can add the required packages.

If you can't find the required localization, then the only option is to use International version (PC00_M99_CALC).

Finally, the multi-currency payroll isn't standard option in SAP payroll due to financial and legal compliance.

For example,
   1. Create a new entry on T-Code : DBCO

Thanks!

Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to create a DB link to an MSSQL DB(Java_Legacy) s...
entry.content:
Please refer to the following steps:

Database Link Setup: S/4HANA to MSSQL on Azure Project Overview

  • Source System: S/4HANA on Private Cloud Edition
  • Target System: Legacy MSSQL Database on Azure
  • Objective: Establish database connectivity for data integration

Prerequisites and Information Required Network Requirements

  • Source S/4HANA system network details (IP ranges, subnets)
  • Target MSSQL server IP/hostname on Azure
  • Port numbers for MSSQL connectivity (typically 1433 for default instance)
  • Firewall rules and security groups configuration between S/4 and Azure

Database Connection Parameters

  • MSSQL server instance name (default or named instance)
  • Database name on the target system
  • Authentication method (SQL Server Authentication recommended)
  • Service account credentials with appropriate database permissions
  • Connection string format based on instance type, see note https://me.sap.com/notes/3260340

SAP System Information

  • S/4HANA system ID and client number
  • Basis administrator contact for coordination
  • Current kernel version and patch level

Step-by-Step Implementation Process

Phase 1: Network Connectivity Setup

  1. Verify network connectivity between S/4HANA and Azure MSSQL
  2. Configure Azure network security groups to allow inbound connections
  3. Test basic network connectivity using telnet to the MSSQL port

Phase 2: SAP Service Request Process

Phase 3: Database Link Configuration

  1. Transaction DBCO Configuration

    • Access T-Code DBCO in your S/4HANA system
    • Create new database connection entry
    • Configure connection parameters based on MSSQL instance type, see note https://me.sap.com/notes/3260340
    • Set database type as "MSS" for Microsoft SQL Server

  2. Connection Parameters Setup

    • Database ID: Unique identifier for your connection
    • Database type: MSS (Microsoft SQL Server)
    • Host name: Azure MSSQL server hostname or IP
    • Port: 1433 (default) or specific port for named instances
    • Database name: Target database name on MSSQL server

Phase 4: Authentication Configuration

  1. Configure database user credentials with appropriate permissions
  2. Set up secure connection parameters
  3. Configure SSL/TLS encryption if required by security policies

Phase 5: Testing and Validation

  1. Connection Testing

    • Test connection via DBCO transaction
    • Verify connectivity status and resolve any errors
    • Check system logs for connection issues

  2. Functional Testing

    • Execute sample SELECT queries to verify data access
    • Test data retrieval performance
    • Validate connection stability under load

entry.title: RAP Later Numbering of multiple instances; matching child entries to parent entries
entry.content:
I have a BDEF that uses late numbering and looks as follows:

managed implementation in class /ipn/bp_i_checklisttype unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for /IPN/I_ChecklistType alias ChecklistType
persistent table eam_cl_cu_type
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
late numbering
{
  create;
  field (readonly) ChecklistType;
  update;
  delete;
  association _Text { create; }
  mapping for eam_cl_cu_type
  {
    ChecklistType = cl_type;
    Inactive = inactive;
  }
}

define behavior for /IPN/I_ChecklistTypeText alias ChecklistTypeText
persistent table EAM_CL_CU_TYPT
lock dependent by _ChecklistType
authorization dependent by _ChecklistType
late numbering
{
  update;
  field (readonly:update) ChecklistType, Language;
  delete;
  association _ChecklistType;
  mapping for EAM_CL_CU_TYPT
  {
    ChecklistType = cl_type;
    Language = spras;
    ChecklistTypeText = cl_type_text;
  }
}

The problem is, when I try and create more than one instance at once, e.g. with the following test code:

    MODIFY ENTITY /ipn/i_checklisttype
      CREATE FIELDS ( inactive )
      WITH VALUE #(
          ( %cid = 'cid1' %control-inactive = if_abap_behv=>mk-on  inactive = '' )
          ( %cid = 'cid2' %control-inactive = if_abap_behv=>mk-on  inactive = '' )
       )
       CREATE BY \_text
       FIELDS ( language checklisttypetext ) "ChecklistType
       WITH VALUE #(
            ( %cid_ref = 'cid1' %target = VALUE #( ( %cid = 'cid1.1' language = sy-langu checklisttypetext = 'Test created with EML' ) ) )
            ( %cid_ref = 'cid2' %target = VALUE #( ( %cid = 'cid2.1' language = sy-langu checklisttypetext = 'Test created with EML' ) ) )

       )
      FAILED   DATA(mod_failed)
      REPORTED DATA(mod_reported)
      MAPPED   DATA(mod_mapped).

When it reaches the ADJUST_NUMBERS method in the implementation class, there is no reliable way to tie back the child entries (ChecklistTypeText) to the respective headers (ChecklistType).

In the example above, it is not a problem, since there is one child (text) entry per header, but if I were to have multiple child entries per header, I would not be able to tell which child belongs to which header.

The only identifier that is passed along to the ADJUST_NUMBERS method in the MAPPED structure is a GUID in %PID, but this is unique on every record, so it does not allow me to tie back an individual child to its header.

entry.title: Re: It‚Äôs not clear which changes need to be finalized bef...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

  1. Only the Tax Box Mappings for IMG VCL_FOT_ATR (configuration activity: Maintain Tax Box Mapping for Advanced Tax Return [103188]) and IMG V_FOT_TBS2 (configuration activity: Define Enhanced Tax Box Structure [103011]) must be released. All other settings are not relevant for the migration in the development system. However, the overall country settings must be available in the other systems, before you can start the migration there. For more information regarding the configuration locks please read https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blogs-by-sap/registration-for-indirect-taxation-abroad-rita-in-2302-a-pragmatic-approach/ba-p/13561685
  2. 'configuration project' is a term used for the 2SL setup. For the 3SL setup, it means that the CBC transports and the fine tuning transports that contain the objects mentioned above must be released.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Security: Integrating Microsoft Sentinel
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition now integrated with Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP 

This blog was co-authored with Martin Pankraz (SAP Security PM, Microsoft) 

In the shared responsibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, most of the security tasks are handled by the cloud service provider ‚Äì SAP in this case. However, in order to obtain a comprehensive picture of your security posture and for comprehensive threat detection, certain information from the application is also needed. For this, SAP provides APIs for security relevant data - such as the Security Audit Log when we‚Äôre speaking about event driven data, but also more static APIs to establish a security dashboard are provided by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.  

Providing this information, however, is ‚Äì quite literally ‚Äì only half of the story. In order to make sense of this information, the receiving solution needs to make sense of the data provided, combine it with relevant data from other systems within the landscape and correlate information with each other. This solution also needs to understand the application that provides the information, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in this case.  

This is why we‚Äôre especially thrilled to announce the Microsoft Sentinel for SAP integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - a cloud-native integration that brings real-time threat detection, investigation, and response to your SAP environment.

Why This Matters  

With Microsoft Sentinel as the receiving end of the security relevant APIs that SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition provides, customers receive a lightweight, scalable, compliant, and AI ready approach to integrate SAP telemetry into their enterprise security operations. 

Our integration delivers exactly that: 

  • Agentless deployment for faster onboarding. 
  • Unified security operations across SAP and non-SAP systems. 
  • Compliance-ready log retention at a fraction of traditional costs. 

What This Release Offers 

  1. 1. AI enabled unified Security Operations 
  • Correlate SAP Cloud events with enterprise telemetry in Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP and Microsoft Defender XDR ready for Microsoft Security Copilot. 
  • Use prebuilt analytics rules, workbooks, and SOAR playbooks to detect and respond to threats like:  
  • Privilege escalations 
  • Unauthorized configuration changes 
  • Suspicious financial transactions 
  1. 2. Compliance-Ready Log Retention 
  • Store SAP logs cost-efficient in Microsoft Sentinel Data Lake for up to 12 years. 
  • Support threat hunting involving SAP on the Sentinel Data lake through KQL jobs. 

Key Benefits 

  • Faster Deployment: Go live in hours, not weeks. 
  • Future-Proof: Built on SAP‚Äôs strategic integration approach using APIs. 
  • Security at Scale: Detect and respond to threats across your entire SAP landscape. 

How It Works 

  1. Deploy the Microsoft Sentinel integration package in SAP Integration Suite. 
  2. Configure your Microsoft Sentinel workspace to start ingesting SAP logs. 
  3. Activate prebuilt content for instant visibility and protection. SAP S/4HANA Cloud ‚Üí SAP Integration Suite ‚Üí Microsoft Sentinel 

What‚Äôs Next 

  • General Availability after the current preview phase. 
  • Upcoming enhancements: Expansion of protection scope to additional communication scenarios provided by SAP. 

Getting Started 

Activate SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Microsoft Sentinel Integration | Azure portal from the Sentinel Content Hub. Provide your connection details for communication scenario 750 and you are good to go. 

Once deployed, we recommend to check AryaG‚Äôs series giving details on how to move to production 

Final Words 

#Kudos to the amazing engineering teams on both sides and our incredible community contributors! 

That's a wrap. Remember: bringing SAP under the protection of your central SIEM isn't just a checkbox - it's essential for comprehensive security and compliance across your entire IT estate. 

Cheers, Patrick & Martin

entry.title: beforeOpenContextMenu is not firing when right-clicking on a group header in sap.ui.table.Analytical
entry.content:
Hi,

I am using an SAPUI5 Analytical Table where grouping is implemented at one level.
When I right-click on a group header, the context menu opens with options such as Ungroup Level and Ungroup All.
Since I am using only one grouping level, I would like to hide one of these options (for example, Ungroup Level).
To achieve this, I tried using the beforeOpenContextMenu event to modify the menu items dynamically. However, this event does not trigger when right-clicking on the group header.
On the other hand, the attachColumnSelect event is triggered correctly when right-clicking on a column header (for sorting and filtering), and I am able to hide unwanted menu items there.
I expect similar behavior when right-clicking on the group header to customize that context menu as well.

Steps to Reproduce:
Use an Analytical Table (sap.ui.table.AnalyticalTable) with one-level grouping enabled.
Right-click on a column header ‚Üí attachColumnSelect triggers correctly.
Right-click on a group header (e.g., ‚ÄúCompany Code = XXXX‚Äù) ‚Üí context menu appears with Ungroup Level and Ungroup All options.
Observe that the beforeOpenContextMenu event does not trigger.

Expected Behavior:
When the user right-clicks on a group header, the beforeOpenContextMenu event should trigger so that developers can modify or hide specific menu options (for example, remove Ungroup Level when only one grouping level is used).

Actual Behavior:
The context menu is displayed when right-clicking on a group header, but the beforeOpenContextMenu event is not fired.

Code Snippet Used:
const oTable = this.byId("dynamicTable");
// Works on column header right-click
oTable.attachColumnSelect((oEvent) => {
    console.log(oEvent);
});

// Not triggered on group header right-click
oTable.attachBeforeOpenContextMenu((oEvent) => {
    console.log("Context menu event triggered:", oEvent);
});

Please let me know if I am missing anything or if there is an alternative way to capture the context menu event on group headers to modify or remove menu options dynamically.

Regards,
Sridevi

entry.title: ICPM 2025‚ÄìInternational Conference on Process Mining
entry.content:
This year, the vibrant city of Montevideo, Uruguay, welcomed around 230 researchers, vendors, and practitioners from across the globe for the seventh International Conference on Process Mining (ICPM). It was a truly special edition‚Äîthe first-ever ICPM held in South America. From October 20 to 24, 2025, participants immersed themselves in five days packed with inspiring talks, hands-on sessions, and networking opportunities.

The program offered something for everyone: cutting-edge research presentations and tool demonstrations, an industry track featuring vendor-led tutorials, real-world use case discussions, and even a hackathon. This unique blend of academic rigor and practical innovation makes ICPM one of a kind‚Äîa meeting point where theory meets practice. Naturally, it‚Äôs also a flagship event for SAP Signavio, where we connect with the broader process mining community and showcase our thought leadership.

In this blog post, we‚Äôll take you behind the scenes of SAP Signavio‚Äôs presence at ICPM 2025‚Äîhighlighting the sessions our colleagues contributed to, the hot topics shaping the future of process mining, and the proud moments when our work took the spotlight with multiple awards.

Felipe Feuerman, Majid Rafiei, Pedro Costa, Adrian Rebmann, Lukas Kirchdorfer at the SAP Signavio stall.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Topics @ ICPM 2025

ICPM once again showcased the full breadth of process mining research‚Äîfrom foundational methods to emerging frontiers. As in previous years, many contributions focused on pushing the boundaries of predictive and prescriptive process monitoring, helping organizations move from understanding what happened to anticipating what will happen next‚Äîand even recommending what to do about it. Researchers also presented novel process discovery techniques, refining how we extract meaningful models from complex event data. A particularly vibrant stream of work explored visualization, explainability, and cross-organizational process mining, emphasizing how we can make process insights more transparent and actionable.

One standout contribution addressed a fundamental question: why do users often struggle to derive insights from process mining results? With its strong practical relevance, this research resonated deeply with practitioners in the field.

Finally, the conference spotlighted two rapidly growing areas‚ÄîGenerative AI and Object-Centric Process Mining‚Äîboth of which are opening exciting new directions for the community and are sure to shape the next wave of innovation.

SAP Signavio @ ICPM 2025

What truly stood out about SAP Signavio‚Äôs presence at ICPM 2025 was the balance between industry leadership and academic excellence. As one of the main sponsors of this year‚Äôs conference, SAP Signavio welcomed visitors at our on-site booth (see photo above), fostering discussions with researchers, customers, and practitioners from around the world. At the same time, our team played an active role in the academic program, contributing several research papers that advanced the state of the art in process mining. The high quality of our work was recognized with two awards‚Äîa proud moment for our teams across Signavio.Next and Signavio Benchmarking.

Industry Track Contribution

Building on last year‚Äôs successful presentation by Gia-Thi Nguyen, our Signavio team once again took the stage in front of a large audience of practitioners and academics. We showcased how SAP Signavio, LeanIX, and WalkMe jointly empower organizations in their business transformation journeys, highlighting our expanding portfolio of AI-driven and agent-based solutions.

Main Track Contribution

Adrian Rebmann (Developer at Signavio.Next) co-authored a main track paper titled ‚ÄúLLMs that Understand Processes: Instruction-tuning for Semantics-Aware Process Mining‚Äù. The work demonstrates how Large Language Models (LLMs) can be effectively fine-tuned to perform diverse process mining tasks with a deep understanding of process semantics.

Workshop Contributions

Our researchers also made a strong impact across multiple workshops:

  • Majid Rafiei (Senior Data Scientist, Signavio Benchmarking) presented ‚ÄúEnriching Object-Centric Event Data with Process Scopes: A Framework for Aggregation and Analysis‚Äù‚Äîco-authored with Timotheus Kampik (Principal Scientist, SAP Signavio) and Gregor Berg (Co-Lead of Signavio.Next)‚Äîat the PQMI workshop, where it earned the Best Paper Award.
  • At the same workshop, Adrian Rebmann and Timotheus Kampik co-authored another paper as part of an ongoing collaboration with researchers from Hasso-Plattner-Institut (HPI).
  • In the Machine Learning for Process Mining workshop, Lukas Kirchdorfer (PhD Student, Signavio.Next) presented research on simplifying neural network architectures for predictive process monitoring, co-authored with Amaan Ansari (former working student) and Sherri Hadian (AI Scientist, Signavio.Next).
  • Finally, Adrian Rebmann contributed to yet another paper on conformance checking, co-authored with two former visiting PhD researchers from the Blue Sky team.
Reviewer Service

Beyond paper contributions, our colleagues were also recognized for their exceptional service to the research community. Timotheus Kampik received an honorable mention for his reviewing efforts, and Majid Rafiei was selected as the Best Reviewer at ICPM 2025‚Äîa testament to our team‚Äôs deep engagement and expertise in advancing process mining research.

Majid Rafiei and Gia-Thi Nguyen (virtually) demonstrating Signavio's capabilities

Conclusion

ICPM 2025 once again demonstrated that process mining is both a well-established discipline and a rapidly evolving field, expanding its horizons with every edition. The conference covered an impressive spectrum of research topics‚Äîfrom foundational methods to the latest trends shaping the future of digital process transformation.

For those eager to dive deeper into the technical details, the entire collection of conference papers is publicly available‚Äîa great opportunity to explore the newest insights and innovations. And if you‚Äôd like to discuss the latest developments firsthand, we invite you to connect with the Blue Sky Team at SAP Signavio and join our weekly research discussions on emerging topics in process mining.

Looking forward, the next ICPM will take place in February 2027, with a special industry-focused event in Germany already planned for summer 2026. Until then, stay tuned for more updates from SAP Signavio as we continue shaping the future of process mining‚Äîtogether with the global research community.

entry.title: Inconsistent Foreign Key naming in Blanket Agreements (OOAT - OAT1) tables
entry.content: hi experts, I have a question regarding the table structure of the Blanket Agreement (Contract) in SAP Business One. I've observed an inconsistency in the foreign key naming between the header and detail tables, which is different from other business documents in the system. The header table [OOAT] uses AbsId (Integer) as its Primary Key. The detail table [OAT1] uses AgrNo (Integer) as the Foreign Key, which points to [@OAGR].AbsId. hi experts, In all other major documents (e.g., Sales Order ORDR/RDR1, Invoice OINV/INV1), the header and detail tables use the same field name ( DocEntry) for the primary and foreign key relationship. My Question: What is the historical or design reason behind this naming inconsistency specifically for the Blanket Agreement tables? Why is the foreign key in [OAT1] named AgrNo instead of AbsId to match the header table? This seems to be a unique case, as other master data like Business Partner (OCRD) and Items (OITM) also use consistent names (CardCode, ItemCode) between their header and child tables. I have verified the relationship with an SQL query, which confirms the join is ON [OOAT].AbsId = [OAT1].AgrNo. Any insights into this design decision would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

entry.title: Re: Show percentage of row totals in story report
entry.content:
Hello jo21,

The only way I can imagine right now, is to create separate calculated measures. So instead of putting the Overall Performance (or Potential) Rating Description into the columns of the cross-tab table, you can create one  restricted measure for each of them. In another calculated measure you can now sum these values up to get the subtotal. And each of the %-columns can now be calculated by the number per Rating  divided by the subtotal column.

I understand if this is not the best idea in case you have a lot of values in the columns, but in your case there are only 3, which means 7 calculated measures can cover your request.

entry.title: Re: COC Operation: Revaluation of COGS vs. Scrapping Fini...
entry.content:
You have configured 71201000 for COGS (VAX/VAY) and also for COC (revaluation). You have activated COGS split for that account. For scrapping (GBB-VNG), you use 71200000. During CKMLCP (actual costing), price differences are revaluated via COC. This causes COGS split logic to apply even for scrapping, which is incorrect.

To distinguish revaluation postings for sales (COGS) and scrapping (cost center consumption) under operation COC in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you should use valuation modifier or account grouping to differentiate the account determination logic‚Äîeven though only one account can be assigned per valuation category and transaction key.

entry.title: Re: Building a position report and wish to see only the l...
entry.content:
Hi,

there is a KBA how to get the latest record 3505244 - How to fetch latest record in Story report? - SAP for Me. The example is based on education, but I have used it to get the latest record for the position object already. In your example the "Last Modified Date" has to be used instead of the "End Date".

Please also note that you have to remove the date filter in general, because we don't know which record was changed most recently. And removing the date filter normally returns a lot of data. So dependent on the amount of records you will get, the report will be very slow.

entry.title: using BAPI_PO_CHANGE to change the Delivery date schedule delivery date and validity end date
entry.content: While using BAPI_PO_CHANGE to change the deliverydate, schedule delivery date and Validity end date for a PO, The release strategy related fields are set to blocked when earlier it was fully released. Is there a way to bypass this release reset logic so that the release related fields won't be changed when I make changes in the delivery dates?

entry.title: Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content:
How should a holistic naming convention store look?

Names are everywhere!

Most customers have specific naming conventions for their development artifacts. Many customers have them in rule books or use ATC to check them, by using the well-known ATC check for naming conventions.

Naming Convention ATC Check

The existing ATC check is very limited, though, as it has no broad coverage of CDS.

Today, we also have new requirements through the use of AI and Generators. When using Joule for Developers, for example, customers expect that their naming conventions are automatically applied. This also holds true when using generators like the RAP generator. 

But how would you expect a naming convention store to look?

1. Option: A central naming convention store

This could be a Fiori app in a central system where the naming conventions are stored. These can then be maintained globally. The ATC check and different tools like generators and AI could connect to that system.

Pros:
   - central maintenance, probably by a central team
   - central excemption process and governance
Cons:
   - Differing rules, according to package and/or system, would be difficult to model
   - The check would come quite late in the development process, i.e. no check by the compiler
   - Excemptions create organizational overhead 


2. Option: Naming convention as source artifact

Store the naming convention as part of the source code, referencing the package and its subpackages.

Pros:
  - Naming convention near the source code, which could even be checked by the compiler
  - Excemptions could be handled locally in the naming convention
 Cons:
  - No central maintenance, probably much more effort to maintain
  - No central governance

The answer probably also depends upon which persona maintains such a naming convention in your company. Is it some central architect or governance team or just the developers?

What do you think?

I am happy to hear your thoughts in the comments. You can also vote for the comments of others.

Disclaimer: this blog post does not imply that SAP will build any product related to naming conventions in the future.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: What‚Äôs New as of 2025-11-03?
entry.content:
Welcome to the latest update of our SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Standard Model What‚Äôs New series! With this update, we‚Äôre excited to introduce enhancements that make managing environments, customizing templates, and monitoring subscription usage more seamless and transparent. 

From advanced metering logic for subscription plans, to support for custom fields in SD and PO functions, and even push notifications for private environment changes, these updates are designed to improve collaboration, flexibility, and operational insights. Let‚Äôs dive into what‚Äôs new and how these features can help you optimize your processes. 

Let‚Äôs take a look at the newest update of SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model! 

Administration | Settings

Subscription Metering Data Settings

SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model now provides enhanced metering capabilities for Runtime DB and BYOD plans. Key features include:

  • Monthly Peak Tracking: System exposes the highest usage value each month with peak occurrence dates
  • Reports: Downloadable historical peak usage reports for both Runtime DB (Capacity Units) and BYOD (GB)
  • UI Integration: View current peak values directly in the Administration Settings screen

For Default/tandd plan (measured in CU):

For BYOD plan (measured in GB):

For more information, see Subscription Metering Data Settings in our Application Help on SAP Help Portal.

Modeling Settings: Customize RFA Template

In our previous What‚Äôs New blog post, we introduced the ability to create custom fields for Finance Accounts Payable, Finance Accounts Payable Items, Finance Accounts Receivable, and Finance Accounts Receivable Items.

Great news! We‚Äôve now added two more RFA types:

  • Sales and Distribution
  • Purchase Order

This enhancement gives you even more flexibility to tailor your integration scenarios and align with your unique business requirements.

For more details, visit the Help Portal ‚Äì Modeling Settings.

Environment Screen | Main

Push Notifications

An enhancement for SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: Extended Environment Access Level Functionality is now available in your tenants. Now when an administrator creates, edits, copies, and deletes a private environment, the users assigned to authorized teams will get an in-app and email notifications about these actions. See sample image below:

That‚Äôs a wrap for this quarter‚Äôs updates! With these new capabilities, SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model continues to evolve to meet your business needs.

Stay tuned for more innovations in the coming releases, and don‚Äôt forget to explore the detailed documentation in the SAP Help Portal for deeper insights.

entry.title: SAFT JPK_KR_PD configuration
entry.content:
Hello,

I'm currently configuring the SAFT JPK_KR_PD report for a polish customer in SAP S4 Hana cloud public, and I have two questions for which I can't find answers :

- When mapping the G/L accounts with "Financial tag " and "Income tax tags", it is possible, as an option, to assign an alternative financial tag to a G/L account => in wich circumstances should this optional tag be assigned?

- My customer has raised a business case where some expenses in an invoice can be only partially relevant for tax. How should those invoices be created, so that the system considers the part relevant for tax and the part which is not relevant for tax in the report ? Should we create an item for the tax relevant part and another one for th non relevant par of the invoice ? Or maybe others settings exist for that business case ?

Thanks for your help

Erwan

entry.title: Dynamic Threshold-Based Background Color for SAC Numeric Point
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I'm looking to dynamically display threshold-based background colors for a Numeric Point widget in SAC.

I know that in SAC Tables, we can easily apply background colors to cells based on thresholds. However, for the Numeric Point widget, it seems only the text color can be customized dynamically‚Äîthere‚Äôs no built-in option to change the background color based on values.

Currently, I‚Äôve placed the Numeric Point inside a Panel, and while the Panel‚Äôs background color can be set manually, it‚Äôs static and doesn‚Äôt update dynamically with the Numeric Point‚Äôs value.

Does anyone have a solution to make the Numeric Point‚Äôs background color dynamic? For example, using custom CSS or SAC scripts?

Any insights would be greatly appreciated! Thanks in advance!

SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: CAP backend service through BTP configured Destination
entry.content:
Dear all,

We are writing to request assistance with a configuration issue on our SAP BTP Cloud Foundry environment. We are encountering a consistent 500 Internal Server Error when our SAPUI5 application attempts to call a CAP backend service through a configured Destination.

System Architecture:

  • Frontend: A SAPUI5 application (UI5 version 1.140.0) deployed on SAP BTP.

  • Backend: An SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) application deployed as a back-end service on the same BTP CF space.

  • Connectivity: The frontend connects to the backend via a BTP Destination named EINV_CAP_BackEnd_SRV.

  • Authentication: The connection is secured using OAuth2ClientCredentials flow with an XSUAA service instance as shown below:

 

 

Problem Description:
When the frontend application makes a call to the OData service endpoint (/odata/v4/catalg/), the request fails with a 500 Internal Server Error.

 



 

Troubleshooting Steps and Findings:
We have performed several tests to isolate the issue, and here is what we have confirmed:

  1. The CAP Backend Service is Working: If we call the CAP service endpoint directly using Postman and provide a manually obtained Bearer Token, we receive a 200 OK response with the expected data. This confirms that the service logic is correct.

  2. The BTP Destination is Working: We have successfully tested the EINV_CAP_BackEnd_SRV destination using the BTP Cockpit's "Check Connection" feature and also by calling the Destination Service API via Postman. In both cases, the destination successfully fetches a valid JWT Bearer Token from the XSUAA service. Here below the evidences:

     




  1. Authentication Flow Seems Partially Correct: We are not receiving 401 Unauthorized or 403 Forbidden errors.

Based on these findings, we believe the issue lies in the interaction between the Approuter, the Destination Service, and the CAP service's security validation.

Configuration Details:

  • Destination: EINV_CAP_BackEnd_SRV

    • Type: HTTP

    • URL: https://d03-e-invoice01-cf01-d03-e-invoice01-cf01-sp01-fatturaz2a9200d4.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/

    • Proxy Type: Internet

    • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

    • Client ID: sb-FatturazioneElettronicaAttiva!t566124

    • Token Service URL: https://d03-e-invoice01.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

  • xs-app.json Route Configuration:

codeJSON

{

"source": "^/odata/v4/catalg/(.*)$",

"target": "/odata/v4/catalg/$1",

"destination": "EINV_CAP_BackEnd_SRV",

"authenticationType": "xsuaa",

"csrfProtection": false

}

 



  • manifest.json DataSource Configuration:

codeJSON

"dataSources": {

"capSrv": {

"uri": "/odata/v4/catalg/",

"type": "OData",

"settings": {

"odataVersion": "4.0"

}

}

}

 



Could someone please assist us in identifying the cause of this 500 error? Any guidance on how to further debug this or what might be misconfigured would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you for your time

entry.title: Re: Query Regarding Automatic Quantity Change in Asset Cards
entry.content:
Hi,

Unlike before in previous SAP Products, the current version of Asset Accounting, so called IAA " Intelligent Asset Accounting" handles things differently. With respect to quantity, it is not managed anymore on asset master record. Asset master just stores the unit of measurement and then if this UOM matches the UOM of the line item to be posted, it will be considered for quantity changes, that happen per ledger. Obviously, the quantity is not stored anywhere in asset but it is calculated on the flay. So, no simple adjustment can be done; no quantity change without a posting!

Best regards, Mick

entry.title: Re: Display measure name with selected variable/prompt value
entry.content:
Hi @deshmukh ,

Kindly try testing the below workaround in your SAC story.

Create a restricted measure in your story with the required measure and date dimesion( below i have taken Fiscal Year of Ledger). 

New Calculation Input Control 'year2' is created for Dimension ' Fiscal Year of Ledger' . 

In the description of the restricted measure , enter the Amount followed by name of the input control created above from the dropdown.

Use this restricted measure in your story instead of the original measure and you can change the value of the input control using the below script(can be added to an event) based on the selected variable value by the user. 

Input control can be hidden during the runtime.

//getting the variable value selected by the user
var year = Table_1.getDataSource().getVariableValues("!CDS_F_2CN0E2PMNHTZPHA0EDX597")[0];
console.log(year.type);

var passyear = cast(Type.SingleVariableValue,year);
var p_year = "K4"+ passyear.value;

//passing the values to the calculation input control year2
year2.getInputControlDataSource().setSelectedMembers(p_year);

Output

Best Regards,

Shivam

entry.title: Secure By Default: SAP S/4HANA 2025 ‚Äì The Security Journey Continues
entry.content:
What began as a bold initiative to strengthen the default security posture of SAP S/4HANA has, over the years, evolved into a core principle of the product. While the journey from concept to execution took time, we‚Äôve now reached a point where Secure By Default is not just an aspiration - it‚Äôs a continuously expanding reality. With each release, more robust security settings are seamlessly integrated, helping customers benefit from enhanced protection without additional effort.

With the release of SAP S/4HANA 2025, also named SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025,  another step was taken by SAP S/4HANA supported by ABAP Platform to cover some additional topics for new installations, conversions, and system copies.

Identical to the former years, Secure By Default settings are applied for

    • SAP S/4HANA 2025 / SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025
    • All SAP products based on S/4HANA Foundation 2025

List of new Secure By Default Settings

In new installations, system copies, and conversions the following security relevant settings and configurations are applied automatically:

    • Add support for TLS1.3 for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA in addition to TLS1.2
    • Adjust the security log of ICM to make it machine-readable for easier integration into SIEM solutions
    • Disable support for SAP logon tickets while still accepting SAP Assertion Tickets
    • Configure a Report-only Content Security Policy (CSP) for faster introduction of a Content Security Policy as second level of defence for S/4HANA
    • Disable the outdated ICM content scan interface as dedicated checks have been introduced in browser-based applications against Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and input validation.

Additional Information

As with SAP S/4HANA 1909, SAP S/4HANA 2020, SAP S/4HANA 2021, SAP S/4HANA 2023 customers will receive the security settings automatically with new installations, system copies and conversions. An opt-out is possible for the security relevant profile parameters but not recommended from SAP side. More details can be found in SAP Note 2926224.

As Secure By Default settings cannot and will not cover all aspects of security settings in S/4HANA systems, we highly recommend customers to perform additional reviews and improvements of their security settings. Good sources are the SAP security whitepapers. Secure by Default settings provide a good starting point, but there are additional security settings and configurations which are either customer specific, cannot be shipped as default or need to be applied on a regular basis (e.g., security patching).

    • Use the SAP-provided tools and services, such as Early Watch Alert, Configuration Validation and System Recommendations in order to display missing security patches. These inform you about gaps in a cost-efficient way.
    • Always introduce disruptive security settings with good timing. Conversion projects and new installations are opportunities to increase security. As a benefit, security testing can be included as part of the testing activities planned within the project. This leverages synergies in the area that has proven to be particularly costly.

Please refer to these blog posts for older SAP S/4HANA releases

    • For SAP S/4HANA 2023 ‚Äì Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog https://blogs.sap.com/2023/10/18/another-chapter-of-secure-by-default-for-sap-s-4hana-2023/
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2022 ‚Äì Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog https://blogs.sap.com/2022/11/03/secure-by-default-returns-with-sap-s-4hana-2022
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2021 ‚Äì Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog The story resumes ‚Äì Secure By Default for SAP S/4HANA 2021
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2020 ‚Äì Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog Secure By Default for SAP S/4HANA 2020
    • For SAP S/4HANA 1909 ‚Äì Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog Secure By Default: Ways To Harden Your Systems At (Almost) No Cost

Complete List of all SAP S/4HANA Secure By Default Settings

Below you can find a complete list of all Secure By Default settings that are included in SAP S/4HANA 2025. Bold entries were added with SAP S/4HANA 2025:

    • Security relevant profile parameters are set to secure values which increases security in areas such as:
        • Mandatory SSL Protection of session logon tickets (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Disable support for SAP logon tickets while still accepting SAP Assertion Tickets (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Protect the RFC gateway against unauthorized RFC call forwarding (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Strong password policies and password hashes (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • Protection of internal system communication (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • Strengthened authorizations system (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Enhanced RFC interface protection (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Enforce TLS1.2-only for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA covering SAP Internet Communication Manager (ICM), SAP Start Service, SAP Host Agent (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Add support for TLS1.3 for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA in addition to TLS1.2 (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Disable the old insecure tickets for trusted / trusting communication (part of S/4HANA 2023)
        • Disable the outdated ICM content scan interface as dedicated checks have been introduced in the browser-based applications against Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and input validation (part of S/4HANA 2025)
    • Security relevant configurations and customizing are set to secure values
        • Prevent usage of non-reference user as reference user (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • 3 parameters were changed to secure defaults in the Transport Management (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Web protection is increased by activation of the UCON HTTP allowlist (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Start authorizations for WebDynpro were enabled for an improved security for Webdynpro applications (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • All available scenarios of the Switchable Authorization Framework (SACF) are activated which adds additional functional authorization checks for technical function modules (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • All available scenarios of the Generic Application Access Rules (SLDW) were activated as defined by SAP development (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Prevent the assignment of users to roles as part of transports to avoid that users get authorizations in higher tiers while importing transports (part of S/4HANA 2023)
    • Security relevant logging was enabled to support traceability and security monitoring
        • Performance, usability and analysis optimized log of RFC and SICF usage to support deactivation of unused RFC function modules and SICF services (part of S/4HANA 2022 and S/4HANA 2023)
        • Security Audit Log is activated what allows customers to trace critical activities in the system (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Activation of table logging for business-critical tables (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • HTTP server and HTTP client log of the SAP Internet Communication Manager is enabled (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Granular logging of Secure By Default activations in application log for easier debugging in conversions (part of S/4HANA 2023)
        • Adjust the security log of ICM to make it machine-readable for easier integration into SIEM solutions (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Configure a Report-only Content Security Policy (CSP) for faster introduction of a Content Security Policy as second level of defence for S/4HANA (part of S/4HANA 2025)
    • HANA for S/4HANA relevant configurations were enabled to improve traceability and encryption
        • SAP HANA Audit Log is switched on for HANAs running SAP S/4HANA. This enables traceability of activities on SAP HANA database level (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Leverage the automated activation of HANA Data at Rest Encryption Features as part of HANA2 SP07 installations to ensure that business data cannot be accessed on file system level (part of S/4HANA 2023)
    • Values of additional security relevant profile parameters were changed in the kernel default

entry.title: Joule enablement process blog - How to get started with Joule in Ariba
entry.content:
Hi there and welcome to my blog. 

My name is Filiz Yasar, I am one of the Solution Value Advisors based in the Netherlands.  The world of procurement is continuously evolving, and with it are the tools and technologies aimed at optimizing organizational spend.  Here, I am excited to present my blog on how artificial intelligence can elevate the user experience in SAP Ariba.

By following these steps and ensuring all prerequisites are met, you can effectively get started with Joule in SAP Ariba applications, enhancing your operational efficiency through AI-powered interactions.

Prerequisites

    • Ensure you have a license for one or more SAP Ariba applications (Guided Buying, Guided Sourcing, Supplier Management) in a supported data center. The currently supported data centers are listed here.
    • You need an enterprise global account on SAP BTP. Joule leverages BTP to simplify complex integration landscapes.
    • Integrate the SAP Ariba application with Identity Authentication as Joule leverages the Identity Authentication Service (IAS) setup.
    • Configure the navigation service of SAP Build Work Zone to support navigation to different applications from Joule and handle role-based access scenarios.
    • Create a subaccount in your global account using the SAP BTP cockpit for provisioning Joule.

Steps to Activate Joule

    • Enable either the Joule Base SKU (8019544) or the Joule Premium SKU (8019164) from the SAP Store.
    • Ensure the necessary BTP services are setup and configured, including:
      • SAP Cloud Identity Services for seamless SSO experience. (Refer this blog for details on SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services).
      • SAP Build Work Zone for navigation and role-based access.

Available Features

    • Provides knowledge-based results from SAP applications, such as SAP Help Documentation.
    • Document Grounding allows uploading customer-owned content for FAQs and policies.
    • Navigate SAP applications using natural language queries.
    • Open applications in new browser tabs with conversation history.
    • Direct entry point to backend systems for tasks like purchase order approvals, job positions creation, etc.

 

Available Skills

  • Guided Buying:
    • Transactional: Get status of purchase requisition, show recent PRs, show approvers of PR, etc.
    • Navigational: View requisition.
  • Guided Sourcing:
    • Transactional: List sourcing events, return RFx status, send reminder emails, etc.
    • Navigational: Go to My Tasks, Go to Sourcing Event.
  • Supplier Management:
    • Transactional: Show primary contact information of supplier, list suppliers in registration/invited status.
  • Multi-Language Support
  • Joule supports multiple languages, including English, German, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Japanese, Korean, Chinese, Vietnamese, Greek, and Polish.

Costing

  • All the mentioned Joule skills are part of Joule base and will not be charged any AI units.

 

Limitations (as of Q3 2025 Release)

  • Multi-ERP Setup Issue:
    • Joule does not currently support multi-tenant consolidation. Run Joule Booster in every child realm to overcome this limitation.

For more information on setting up Joule please look at our setup Guide.

Thank you for reading my blog!
